Recall the definition of a limit in a topological space: A point x in X is the limit of a sequence (x_n) if for every open neighborhood U of x, there exists a natural number N such that for all n > N, x_n belongs to U.

In our topology, the open sets containing 0 are {0}, {0,1,2}, and {0,1,2,3,4}. Let's check if 0 is the limit of the sequence (1/n) with respect to these open sets.

Since 0 is not the limit of the sequence (1/n) in this topology, there is no limit for the sequence (1/n) in the given topological space X.
